2.en: and The Underground man is like an original incel

3.en: because he takes so much pride in his suffering.

4.en: To 10% of women in America aged 18 to 24 are on OnlyFans.

6.en: Ooh, it's really at home in analytic philosophy.

7.en: It appeals to that combative instinct in a young man's intellect,

8.en: and it makes him feel like he's on a side.

9.en: The incels take it as a badge of honor.

10.en: Most people who are in religious studies departments are some sort of atheist.

11.en: I think there's a reason that the Buddha had to abandon his family,

12.en: that Jesus didn't have a family to begin with.

13.en: The great entrepreneurs like Elon and Steve Jobs have terrible private lives,

14.en: and a lot of the great philosophers, most of them aren't married.

15.en: Bronze Age pervert or other incel type voices.

16.en: They're wrong about that because they have such a small understanding of Nietzsche.

17.en: Nietzsche always comes across a little bit as insecure.

18.en: He's still going through a puberty, right?

20.en: He's still showing the tough guy ish.

21.en: Something terrible has happened in modern dating.

22.en: 5% to 10% of young American women are on OnlyFans.

23.en: Birth rates have plummeted below subsistence in developed nations.

24.en: And an unbelievable number of young men identify as Incels;

25.en: men who proudly advertise that they can’t get any girls.

26.en: My guest today is Notre Dame’s David O’Connor.

27.en: He’s going to diagnose what has gone wrong,

28.en: show us how incels and OnlyFans are two sides of the same coin,

29.en: and what you can do today to secure a happy love life.

30.en: In this interview, Professor O’ Connor will rescue classical resources

31.en: from the platonic and Catholic traditions, to help you survive modern dating.

32.en: What are young men doing wrong in dating today?

33.en: A lot of young men are actually fearful about

34.en: letting women know that they’re attracted to them.

35.en: And it’s as if they’ve lost confidence in their own erotic agency somehow.

36.en: It’s important that they just are bold enough

37.en: to let a woman see that they’re interested in her as a woman.

38.en: I’ve told students over and over again,

39.en: I do not believe in this notion that, “Well, we should be friends first.”

41.en: I don’t think that friendship and an erotic connection, are somehow continuous things.

42.en: I think they’re both valuable things.

43.en: But I think they’re quite different things.

44.en: And I think that one of the things that’s wrong,

45.en: and it can’t be wrong just with men, it must be wrong with couples,

46.en: that’d be the first thing I want to emphasize.

47.en: I think that young men and women of that age,

49.en: and therefore, their erotic power, is at its greatest,

50.en: I think that seeing themselves as couples,

51.en: rather than seeing themselves as just men interested in women and women interested in men,

52.en: but really seeing themselves as couples,

53.en: I think that’s very diminished in contemporary…

54.en: At least the kind of contemporary elite culture

55.en: that the young people I’m around the most are a part of.

56.en: So that’s one of the first things I would tell a young man

57.en: that, have confidence in your own erotic agency

58.en: which makes you want to be part of a couple.

59.en: It’s not that, somehow, you’re on this individual search for something

60.en: and that thing happens to be a woman.

61.en: It’s that you are looking for somebody else

62.en: who also feels a certain sense of incompleteness about themselves,

63.en: and somebody who wants to live as a couple.

64.en: I’ve talked to lots of young women,

65.en: and I’m saying young… 22 year olds are not young,

66.en: from the point of view of falling in love

67.en: and using their erotic potency to create a couple.

68.en: They’re not young. They’re not too young.

70.en: How old is still young? Is 30 young? It’s not.

71.en: So to me, that’s part of where the energy is,

72.en: is to let people know; you’re not too young.

73.en: That is a fear, that they’re too young.

74.en: No, you’re not too young. You are ready.

75.en: You can feel the energy in you for this.

77.en: You’re not going to have that in the same way forever.

78.en: When you’ve been teaching for a long time, people often ask you, you know,

79.en: “Are your students different?” And for a long, long time I always said,

80.en: “No, they’re not really that much different.”

81.en: When I saw them become different, was in the financial crisis in 2008-2009.

82.en: Notre Dame families are mostly very secure, very well off.

83.en: But somehow, that financial downturn in 2009,

84.en: it embedded an anxiety about the future that my students never really had.

85.en: And now, the college students who are coming to us, having caught by osmosis,

86.en: the anxieties of their parents about their kids’ futures.

88.en: Notre Dame families were richer than ever,

89.en: and the childrens’ financial prospects were better than ever.

90.en: But that isn’t what’s at the heart of agency, is it?

92.en: And they were much more fearful about that.

94.en: gets layered on top of this fearful erotic agency.

95.en: The notion that there’s something not quite sophisticated or elite

96.en: about being a young man who, when he meets an attractive woman,

97.en: thinks of her as, she might be my wife.

99.en: Now, I don’t say that’s the thing you say on a first date.

102.en: Yes. That’s a big thing in a human life.

103.en: That, that’s the way attraction presents itself to you.

104.en: That you’re finding a woman attractive, or a woman finding a young man attractive,

105.en: that presents itself to you as tapping into something very deep in your own powers.

106.en: That power to become that kind of a couple.

107.en: There’s an even more extreme version of men losing their erotic agency

108.en: that has culminated into the incel movement.

109.en: Are you familiar with this? The involuntary celibates?

110.en: Yeah. I’d rather not be aware of it, but you can’t really avoid it.

111.en: Yeah. It’s a huge… It truly is a movement.

112.en: And if you’re around intellectual high motive young men,

113.en: you are going to run into language you can tell is coming out of some of this.

114.en: Right. And so, of course, there’s been sexually frustrated men throughout history.

115.en: I think what makes this movement unique is three things.

116.en: Number one, is whereas before, some of them… It was embarrassing, right,

117.en: to not be able to win over a woman;

118.en: the incels take it as a badge, at the very least, and sometimes a badge of honor.

119.en: Number two, is that whereas before,

120.en: they might attribute their lack of success to individual issues,

121.en: but now, it’s taken a political and conspiratorial bend,

122.en: that what they call, ‘the Chads,’ the handsome men

123.en: and, ‘the Stacys,’ the beautiful women, are in some sense, conspiring.

124.en: The dating apps are making markets too liquid,

125.en: that there’s an active conspiracy, almost like 9-11.

126.en: And the third one, is the very fact that this is a movement to begin with.

127.en: That there’s a huge swathe of American, and I think

128.en: maybe even global young men, are involved in this circumstance.

129.en: So what do you make of that? And do you see that as

130.en: the further escalation of this loss of erotic power?

131.en: Yeah. The incel thing… Look, I am not a native inhabitant of the online world.

132.en: I only get it from talking to young men,

133.en: or reading Bronze Age Pervert and

134.en: finding out that young men actually do talk about living in the longhouse, right.

135.en: Which means there’s something a little comic about it to me.

137.en: But I think it deserves to be taken seriously,

138.en: because it hardens some young men in their sense

139.en: that the war between the sexes is a real war.

141.en: And that’s a terrible place to live, of course.

142.en: That’s an awful place to live.

143.en: Now, young women have their own forms of this,

144.en: but the incel thing, that’s focused on men.

145.en: And it attracts a lot of very intelligent young men, right?

147.en: So when I talk to young men who’ve been influenced by these things,

148.en: I emphasize to them that when you’re still intellectually young,

149.en: one of the things you’re very attracted to is being smart.

150.en: And that’s quite a corrupting motive sometimes.

151.en: You have to help people get beyond the showoff-iness of that.
